task: The user has been unable to send MMS messages using their messaging app for the past few hours. Customer name: John Smith, phone number: 555-123-2002, current location: at home in the United States. They will consider the issue resolved when an MMS message can be successfully sent.

messages.content: Hi, I‚Äôm having trouble sending MMS messages on my phone for the past few hours. I‚Äôd like some help to fix this so I can send picture messages again.

I can help with that. To get started, I need to identify your account so I can check your line‚Äôs settings.

How would you like to verify your account?
- Phone number on the account
- Customer ID
- Full name and date of birth

Also, to narrow this down faster, please let me know:
- Can you make/receive regular calls and texts right now?
- Are you connected to Wi‚ÄëFi, and is Wi‚ÄëFi Calling turned on?
- Are you currently traveling or in an area where you might be roaming?
- What brand/model of phone are you using?
messages.reasoning_content: Plan: 1) Verify user identity per policy. 2) Gather context: can send texts, receive calls, use mobile data; if on Wi-Fi and Wi-Fi Calling status; traveling/roaming. 3) Run diagnostics: check_status_bar, check_network_status, check_apn_settings, can_send_mms. 4) Follow MMS troubleshooting flow: ensure cellular service + mobile data, correct APN/MMSC, network not 2G, toggle Wi-Fi Calling off if interfering, grant storage/SMS permissions to messaging app. 5) If line suspended or roaming disabled and user is traveling, address accordingly. 6) Reboot after APN reset. 7) Confirm fix.

Thanks, John. I‚Äôve found your account using 555-123-2002. I see you have multiple lines on the account. To proceed with troubleshooting, could you confirm which line/phone number you‚Äôre having trouble sending MMS from right now?

In the meantime, here‚Äôs how we can check the basics:
- Calls and texts: The easiest way is to simply try placing a short outbound call and sending a regular SMS text message. If they go through, that tells us basic service is working. Let me know the results.
- Wi‚ÄëFi and Wi‚ÄëFi Calling: Please open your phone‚Äôs settings and check:
  - Wi‚ÄëFi: Is it on, and which network are you connected to?
  - Wi‚ÄëFi Calling: Is it enabled or disabled?
- Phone brand/model: Please tell me the make and model (e.g., iPhone 14 Pro, Samsung Galaxy S23). If you‚Äôre unsure, you can usually find this in Settings > About phone.

Once you confirm the affected line and those details, I‚Äôll guide you step-by-step through the checks and fixes to get picture messages working again.

I‚Äôm having trouble sending MMS from my line at 555-123-2002.

Here‚Äôs what I found based on your instructions:
- I can‚Äôt send MMS messages with my messaging app right now.
- My phone currently does not have a network signal, and mobile data is disabled. 
- Wi-Fi is turned off.
- Wi-Fi Calling is turned on.

Would you like me to try placing a call and sending a regular SMS next, or should I enable mobile data and Wi-Fi first? Also, let me know if you still need the phone brand/model‚ÄîI‚Äôll check that for you if needed.

Thanks for the details. Since you have no cellular signal and mobile data is disabled, let‚Äôs focus on restoring basic cellular service first. MMS needs either a working cellular signal with mobile data on or a working Wi‚ÄëFi Calling connection over Wi‚ÄëFi. Since Wi‚ÄëFi is off, Wi‚ÄëFi Calling won‚Äôt help right now.

Let‚Äôs proceed step by step:
1) Quick checks you can do now:
- Airplane Mode: If Airplane Mode is on, turn it off.
- Mobile Data: Please turn Mobile Data on once we get a signal.

2) Try a basic connectivity test:
- With Mobile Data off, try placing a short outbound call and sending a regular SMS.
- Tell me whether the call connects and the SMS sends. This will tell us if basic service is present.

3) If you still see no signal after turning off Airplane Mode:
- Reinsert the SIM card (or use your phone‚Äôs ‚Äúreseat SIM‚Äù option if available).
- Restart the phone after reinserting the SIM.

4) After you have a signal:
- Keep Wi‚ÄëFi turned on (so Wi‚ÄëFi Calling can work if needed) and Mobile Data turned on.
- Try sending a picture message again and let me know what happens.

A couple of quick questions to tailor the steps:
- What is your phone‚Äôs make and model? (e.g., iPhone 14 Pro, Samsung Galaxy S23)
- In your status bar, do you see any ‚ÄúNo Signal‚Äù or ‚ÄúEmergency calls only‚Äù icon?

If the steps above don‚Äôt help, I can walk you through deeper checks (network mode preferences, APN settings, Wi‚ÄëFi Calling toggle, and app permissions). But first, please:
- Confirm Airplane Mode is off
- Try a call and SMS
- Let me know the phone model

I‚Äôll take it from there.
messages.reasoning_content: We need to diagnose cellular service first. The phone has no signal and mobile data disabled. Wi-Fi Calling is on. MMS requires cellular service and mobile data or Wi-Fi Calling if supported, but since no signal, Wi-Fi Calling might not help if not connected to Wi-Fi. Steps: 1) Have user check SIM status to ensure SIM active; 2) Check Airplane mode; 3) Check APN settings after getting service; 4) Ensure mobile data enabled; 5) Ensure Wi-Fi is on to support Wi-Fi Calling; 6) Try calls/SMS once service restored; 7) If Wi-Fi Calling interferes, turn it off after service works; 8) Check network mode (avoid 2G); 9) Run can_send_mms check; 10) Reset APN if needed; 11) Reboot device. Ask for phone make/model and to toggle airplane mode off if on. Ask to enable Wi-Fi and keep Wi-Fi Calling on temporarily for calling, but focus on restoring cellular service first. Also, check line suspension/resume? But we haven't fetched line details. We should get line details for L1001 (likely 555-123-2002) to see if line is active and suspension. We should also get data usage? Not needed for MMS but for data. But no signal, so likely line status. Plan: Fetch line details for 555-123-2002; but we don't have a tool to map phone number to line ID. Customer's line_ids are L1001, L1002, L1003. We could fetch details for each until match. But better to instruct diagnostics steps that user can do: check status bar, check network status, check sim status. Since policy says to use tools to guide actions; we can ask the user to run device-side diagnostics: check_status_bar, check_network_status, check_sim_status. Provide step-by-step. Ask to toggle airplane mode off and reseat SIM if needed. Meanwhile, since we can, fetch line info for L1001 to see if line is active, suspension_start_date, roaming status.

Great‚Äîthanks for confirming calls and SMS are working.

To find your phone‚Äôs make and model:
- Open Settings
- Go to About phone (or Device info / About device)
- Look for sections like Model name and/or Model number

Once you have that, please proceed with the APN reset:
- Open Settings
- Go to Mobile Network / Cellular Network / Network & Internet (varies by device)
- Select your mobile network / SIM profile
- Open APN (Access Point Names)
- Choose the option to Reset to default or Restore default APNs (some devices show a menu icon with ‚ÄúReset‚Äù or a ‚ÄúReset APN‚Äù button)
- Confirm the reset

After resetting the APN:

Try these two checks next:
1) Alternate messaging app test

- Try sending a picture message
- If it works, we can focus on resetting the built-in ‚Äúmessaging‚Äù app or its data/cache

2) Full APN entry details
- On many devices, not all APN fields are visible unless you tap into ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù for the active APN or scroll further down. Please edit the current APN entry (‚Äúinternet‚Äù) and check if you can view and share:

  - MMS Port

  - APN Roaming Protocol
  - Bearer/Network mode options (if listed)

If your phone still doesn‚Äôt show those fields, let me know and we‚Äôll proceed with additional steps.

Separately, a few quick housekeeping items to try while gathering the above:
- Carrier settings update: If your phone has a ‚ÄúCarrier Settings Update‚Äù option (often in Settings > About phone > Carrier or Mobile network), check for and apply any update, then restart.
- Network settings reset: If available, use the ‚ÄúReset Network Settings‚Äù option (note: this clears Wi‚ÄëFi passwords and Bluetooth pairings). After the reset, set up Mobile Data and Data Roaming again, keep Wi‚ÄëFi off for an initial test, and retry an MMS.

Once you share your phone make/model and the full APN details (or the alternate app result), I‚Äôll guide you through the precise adjustments needed. If those steps still don‚Äôt resolve it, I can arrange escalation for further investigation.

I understand the frustration‚Äîyou‚Äôve done everything right so far. Let‚Äôs continue with the carrier and network resets.

Please do this in order:
1) Carrier Settings Update
- In Settings > About phone (or Settings > Mobile network/Carrier), check for a carrier update
- If available, install it and restart the phone
- After restart, with Wi‚ÄëFi off, Mobile Data and Data Roaming on, try sending an MMS

2) Reset Network Settings (if step 1 doesn‚Äôt resolve it)
- Use the Reset Network Settings option
- After the reset, you‚Äôll need to re-select your carrier, re-enable Mobile Data and Data Roaming, and re-enter Wi‚ÄëFi passwords if needed
- Keep Wi‚ÄëFi off for the first test
- Try sending a picture message again

3) If it still fails after the network reset:
- Turn Wi‚ÄëFi back on, keep Wi‚ÄëFi Calling OFF, and try one more MMS over Wi‚ÄëFi

Please share your phone‚Äôs make and model when you have it. If the issue persists after the above steps, I‚Äôll arrange escalation for further investigation.
